Posts.Content: I was advised to have an ultra-accurate PSA test, even though my PSA from a regular tests is less that 0.1. I'm wondering if that degree of accuracy is an indicator of anything? So it's 0.05, is that even enough to worry about? I was at 20 before surgery..I'd think anything less than 0.1 is fine. Thoughts?? Thanks.
Posts.Signature: Age 67, good health, just peeing slowly 7/14 first physical this millennium. PSA 9. Giant prostate 130gms. 10/14 PSA 14. Biopsy 2/12 positive, T1C 12/14 PSA 19 11/14 Prostate deemed too large for radiation 03/15 DiVinci Prostatectomy Dr. Patel (Recommend!) 5% tumor area (20% if normal size prostate) clear margins 05/15 PSA <0.1, testosterone normal 05/15 Still continence issues and ED issues. but improving. Probably due to prostate size. 08/01 PSA <0.1, testosterone low normal 08/07 Continence slowly improving, but still problems. Starting to address ED issue

Posts.Title: Near total continence 8 days post op--is this possible?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JustBrandon good luck, and all the best. You can now ease your mind sime by knowing you can decide to treat it should it at any time indicate progression or higher gleason grade discovered on future biopsy. Thanks. Met with Dr. slipperyfinger today. Confirmed watchful waiting path...return for PSA in 2 months. Gonna address oversized prostate (125cc) with a combination of diet and medication. Surprisingly, I don't have serious affects from enlarged prostate. but it limits my options. I take Effexor. There's a rare but potentially severe side effect of the medication...prostatitis and/or enlarged prostate. Gotta talk with my shrink about this issue. Al
Posts.Title: Another Newbie

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by LIBMRDUCKS Hi Aloysius, sorry I do not have for sure answer for you, but I'm guessing that parts f,h, and i are a poor attempt to describe the 3 cores that are positive. Part (f) is the (LA) core, Part (h) is the (RM) core, and Part (i) is the (RA) core. I have never seen the "ERG POSITIVE" or "PTEN". It is possible the pathologist trained outside the U.S. or Canada and these are interpretative of his language. I would get a 2nd opinion from a different pathologist and see if the terminology clears things up, for all of us that stumped. I wish you the best of luck. Rob I have since found out those are related to genetic markers. New technology. Went to the radiation oncologist yesterday. Explained it. Leaning towards watchful waiting. Thanks for the replies.
Posts.Title: Another Newbie

Posts.Content: Hello! New to forum, but I'm afraid I must start out with a question. I'm 67, PSA 15. just recently had biopsy, T1c, Gleason 6, 3 sites, max. 20 %. There's a note at the bottom of the results which reads: Parts f,h, and i are all "ERG POSITIVE" and "PTEN NEGATIVE". I can't find the meaning of this. Has this been posted here previously, or can someone answer it, or direct to an answer? Thank you! Al
Posts.Title: Another Newbie

Posts.Content: Thanks, Chuck. There's a following statement: (No loss of tumor suppressor). Therefore this adenocarcinoma is slightly more aggressive than the usual Gleason 3+3=6 adenocarcinoma. This isn't the place I want to see the word aggressive.........

Posts.Title: Another Newbie

Posts.Content: I've been 2 months now and still have little control when I'm active. Doc says it's normal, especially after removing a giant prostate like I had. Well, that's easy for them to say, isn't it?? I leak a couple pints a day, and I THINK it's getting better........but not fast enough. Depends (not the diapers) work great..I swear one will hold a 6 pack. I'm also trying medication for overactive bladder. Try to avoid irritants like caffeine and alcohol. We lost one sphincter with the prostate which doesn't help. Without the restriction of an oversized prostate, plus the loss of one sphincter, some of us have problems. Do your exercises, cut back on irritants, it will improve....or so I'm told.

Posts.Title: Visit with Urologist, Next step for Incontinence

Posts.Content: I still have stress incontinence problems after 3 months, but I'm beginning to believe it's a mechanical problem. No problem at night, but with activity/vibration I have issues. Pick up something heavy, then go take a shower and change. Ironically, I can stop peeing midstream, so I know it's not a control issue. My doc and I are exploring "overactive bladder" possibility. My prostate was so enlarged (130 g) that the urethra was compressed..possibility the bladder became "stronger" to force fluid through the restriction. After surgery I felt like I could pee on the ceiling. I've been taking Myrbetriq for a couple weeks, and it seems it is beginning to help.

Posts.Title: Visit with Urologist, Next step for Incontinence

Posts.Content: Not everyone regains normal functions quickly. Post surgery with robotics is fairly easy, except the first night. Be prepared to leave your dignity at the door. Diets are pretty bland and not easy to get at restaurants, if you're planning to stay near the hospital. Riding in a car for more than an hour can be a problem. If you stay somewhere, make sure it has a big bathroom and a kitchenette. Wear baggy pants, dark in color.

Posts.Title: Visit with Urologist, Next step for Incontinence

Posts.Content: I'm frustrated with the incontinence issue, but its only been 7 week now. A year seems like an eternity to put up with this problem. ED? Gotta get a handle on the incontinence first. I am fine at night (relatively), so I know the controls work, it's just getting them to work while I'm working. The nagging question is..some guys are fine a week or 2 after surgery, why not me?? I'm trying some medicine for overactive bladder, which seems to help. Doc says the bladder is also a muscle, and after years of forcing drainage through a 130 cc restrictive prostate, it's more powerful than it needs to be. Makes sense to me.
Posts.Title: What happens after DaVinci surgery?

Posts.Content: Regaining continence is a person by person situation. After 4 months, I'm still not anywhere near continent..others have better results, and even worse results. I've been taking Myrbetriq for overactive bladder, and it seems to help. Before starting it, I believe I could pee on the ceiling..now, just to the top of the door. Just too much pressure. I can't cough or lift anything without an issue. I had a huge 130g prostate which restricted flow for years. Bladder became a world class athlete to overcome restriction. Now, bladder just merrily does its thing with no restriction. Kegels helped with normal retention, but "urge incontinency" still remains. Real frustrating. I've gone from 6 pads to 2-3 daily, IF I don't cough or pick up anything heavy. Walking makes the situation worse, as does vibration from riding the mower, or going out fishing in the ocean.
Posts.Signature: Age 67, good health, just peeing slowly 7/14 first physical this millennium. PSA 9. Giant prostate 130gms. 10/14 PSA 14. Posts.Title: Catheter out. What should I expect

Posts.Content: Interesting..thank you! After 6 months, I still have issues when I pick stuff up. 70 lbs, and I soak a pad. concrete block..just a quick spurt. Otherwise, I can go all day with one pad, if I wanted. Deep cough has the same affect. Tried some Myrbetriq, which seemed to help. Was your prostate enlarged? Mine was 130g. I suspect that may have contributed to my current issue, as the prostate became stronger to overcome the flow restriction.

Posts.Title: Advance Sling 8 week post op visit with Surgeon/Urologist

Posts.Content: Not me. Before the procedure I was in a truly foul mood. Probably the worst of my life. Just plain nasty. Not a desirable event to look forward to. Afterward, a little more forgiving, but too late now. Make the best of it. Be prepared to give up any vestige of dignity. You'll be on a special diet. Wear baggy clothes to hide your bag. You'll feel surprisingly well, despite the Foley catheter. Exercise, walk, stay close to a bathroom facility. You'll survive, but you're never the same.

Posts.Title: Prematurely... looking for advice

Posts.Content: Don't overdue it! You may feel "normal", but you're still healing. Don't expect everything to work normally for a while. Healing for some of us takes a while. Wear dark pants..they don't show wet spots. Get rid of the diapers as soon as you can. Go to large pads.
Posts.Signature: Age 67, good health, just peeing slowly 7/14 first physical this millennium. PSA 9. Giant prostate 130gms. 10/14 PSA 14. Biopsy 2/12 positive, T1C 12/14 PSA 19 11/14 Prostate deemed too large for radiation 03/15 DiVinci Prostatectomy Dr. Patel (Recommend!) 5% tumor area (20% if normal size prostate) clear margins 05/15 PSA <0.1, testosterone normal 05/15 Still continence issues and ED issues. but improving. Probably due to prostate size. 08/01 PSA <0.1, testosterone low normal 08/07 Continence slowly improving, but still problems. Starting to address ED issue
Posts.Title: One day after surgery.

Posts.Content: Like Highlander, I had a huge prostate...130 gms. After 4 months, I still have incontinence issues. Recently I started on a bladder control medication..Myrbetriq. My local doc said that since the bladder is a muscle, it builds up strength to force drainage through an oversize, restrictive prostate. After surgery I think I could pee on the ceiling. As such, It's often difficult for the remaining "shut-off" valve to work effectively with such overwhelming pressure from the bladder. The first couple months were miserable...the control circuits still worked, but shut-off was ineffective. Recently, I've gotten significantly better. Why? Exercise, time, Myrbetriq? Dunno. After surgery I was pretty pissed off (oops, Freudian slip?) Everyone says "it will get better". Great. Easy for YOU to say...you're not peeing down your leg. Well, it IS getting better, but I'm pretty impatient. However, I've got a client with a good attitude. He asked me what I had for breakfast.."ham sandwich". Beer after dinner? "hell yes". did I enjoy them? "you bet". Well, if I hadn't had surgery, I eventually wouldn't be enjoying those, would I? Hmmm...he's gotta point. A competent surgeon retains the nerves which control incontinence and impotency. As undesirable as it sounds, time (sometimes a lot of time) does seem to allow these functions to return.
Posts.Signature: Age 67, good health, just peeing slowly 7/14 first physical this millennium. PSA 9. Giant prostate 130gms. 10/14 PSA 14. Biopsy 2/12 positive, T1C 12/14 PSA 19 11/14 Prostate deemed too large for radiation 03/15 DiVinci Prostatectomy Dr. Patel (Recommend!) 5% tumor area (20% if normal size prostate) clear margins 05/15 PSA <0.1, testosterone normal 05/15 Still continence issues and ED issues. but improving. Probably due to prostate size. 08/01 PSA <0.1, testosterone low normal 08/07 Continence slowly improving, but still problems. Starting to address ED issue
Posts.Title: Biopsy is positive for cancer ... now what?

Posts.Content: I've got issues after 2+months, and I suspect my problems are the result of a grossly enlarged (130g) prostate. My local urologist, who I trust, indicates that my progress is not unusual, and assures me there are cures. I'm trying medication for overactive bladder. There's pelvic slings which remove pressure on the system. I'm pretty good at night, and can stop urinating in mid-stream, but movement causes momentary spurts. Since the control system works, we've just got to figure out how to improve its function.

After surgery I was pretty pissed off (oops, Freudian slip?) Everyone says "it will get better". Great. Easy for YOU to say...you're not peeing down your leg. Well, it IS getting better, but I'm pretty impatient. However, I've got a client with a good attitude. He asked me what I had for breakfast.."ham sandwich". Beer after dinner? "hell yes". did I enjoy them? "you bet". Well, if I hadn't had surgery, I eventually wouldn't be enjoying those, would I? Hmmm...he's gotta point. A competent surgeon retains the nerves which control incontinence and impotency. As undesirable as it sounds, time (sometimes a lot of time) does seem to allow these functions to return.
Posts.Signature: Age 67, good health, just peeing slowly 7/14 first physical this millennium. PSA 9. Giant prostate 130gms. 10/14 PSA 14. Biopsy 2/12 positive, T1C 12/14 PSA 19 11/14 Prostate deemed too large for radiation 03/15 DiVinci Prostatectomy Dr. Patel (Recommend!) 5% tumor area (20% if normal size prostate) clear margins 05/15 PSA <0.1, testosterone normal 05/15 Still continence issues and ED issues. but improving. Probably due to prostate size. 08/01 PSA <0.1, testosterone low normal 08/07 Continence slowly improving, but still problems. Starting to address ED issue
Posts.Title: Biopsy is positive for cancer ... now what?

Posts.Content: Don't overdue it! You may feel "normal", but you're still healing. Don't expect everything to work normally for a while. Healing for some of us takes a while. Wear dark pants..they don't show wet spots. Get rid of the diapers as soon as you can. Go to large pads.

Posts.Title: One day after surgery.

Posts.Content: The radiation oncologist I visited stated flatly that an enlarged prostate absolutely precluded radiation treatment. Too hard to assure the pellets would affect the necessary areas. Mine was 130 grams. Further, if the radiation is unsuccessful, and you've aged and/or your health has deteriorated, you may no longer be a candidate for radical prostatectomy.
Posts.Title: need help about prostate cancer

Posts.Content: 3 months and and only mediocre control. Essentially dry at night..prostrate seems to help the prostate. Appears to be overactive bladder from grossly enlarged prostate, taking (trying) myrbetriq. Everything feels different for me also. Ironically, I can stop peeing midstream at will, but can't control urination when working.

Posts.Title: A Return to Continence

Posts.Content: I'm the same way, and it's definitely a male ego thing which can be hard to deal with, especially at your age. I still enjoying looking, but my little buddy has lost interest. Don't think it's a control issue in my case, cuz occasionally he starts to get that certain feeling, but then the interest goes away. No, I don't think you and I are whining children. Maybe it's the "glass half full, half empty" thing, which I also don't understand. I see a glass that's simply too big. In my case, beer helps...........

Posts.Title: How do You cope?

Posts.Content: Is the prostate enlarged? My recommendation? First, read Dr. Patrick Walsh's book on the prostate, surgery options, and results. Next, come back and discuss your case with this forum. Do NOT make a decision without reading his book.
